title: Byron Trott
text:
Byron David Trott (born December 2, 1958) is the founder, chairman and CEO of <a href="BDT%20Capital%20Partners">BDT Capital Partners</a>, a <a href="merchant%20bank">merchant bank</a> that provides advice and capital to family and founder-led companies. Formerly, Trott was <a href="vice%20chairman">vice chairman</a> of Investment Banking at <a href="Goldman%20Sachs">Goldman Sachs</a>. <a href="Warren%20Buffett">Warren Buffett</a> has called Trott the only banker he trusts.
Early life and education.
Raised in <a href="Union%2C%20Missouri">Union, Missouri</a>, Trott received an AB from the <a href="University%20of%20Chicago">University of Chicago</a> in 1981, and an <a href="MBA">MBA</a> from the University of Chicago <a href="Booth%20School%20of%20Business">Booth School of Business</a> in 1982. As an undergraduate, he played on the varsity <a href="Chicago%20Maroons">baseball</a> and <a href="Chicago%20Maroons%20football">football</a> teams, and joined the Chi Upsilon chapter of <a href="Phi%20Gamma%20Delta">Phi Gamma Delta</a>. Trott was the 1981 recipient of the <a href="Amos%20Alonzo%20Stagg">Amos Alonzo Stagg</a> Medal, an award presented to the senior male student-athlete at the University of Chicago with the best overall record for academics, athletics and character.
Professional career.
In 1982, Trott joined <a href="Goldman%20Sachs">Goldman Sachs</a> as a <a href="stockbroker">stockbroker</a>, joining Goldman's <a href="investment%20banking">investment banking</a> division in 1988 and serving underneath future U.S. Treasury Secretary <a href="Henry%20Paulson">Henry Paulson</a>. He eventually rose to become vice chairman of investment banking at Goldman Sachs. He advised many of the wealthiest families and closely held companies in deals ranging from the $23 billion Mars-Wrigley combination, the <a href="Pritzker%20family">Pritzker</a>s’ $4.5 billion sale of <a href="Marmon%20Holdings">Marmon Holdings</a> to <a href="Berkshire%20Hathaway">Berkshire Hathaway</a>, and the $5 billion capital infusion from Berkshire Hathaway into Goldman Sachs in September 2008 during the financial crisis.
Trott left Goldman Sachs in early 2009 to strike out on his own. He runs Chicago-based BDT Capital Partners. BDT Capital Partners is a merchant bank that provides long-term capital and advice through its affiliate BDT & Company to help family and founder-led businesses pursue their strategic and financial objectives. BDT Capital Partners manages more than $9 billion across its investment funds from its global limited partner investor base. Among the fund’s investments are a partnership with the Stephen family in <a href="Weber-Stephen%20Products">Weber-Stephen Products</a>, a manufacturer of barbecue grills; a minority stake in <a href="Pilot%20Flying%20J">Pilot Flying J</a>, which operates U.S. highway rest stops and is controlled by Tennessee's Haslam family; a minority investment in <a href="Tory%20Burch%20%28company%29">Tory Burch LLC</a>; the <a href="Wrigley%20Building">Wrigley Building</a> in Chicago; a partnership with the Rales family in <a href="Colfax%20Corporation">Colfax</a>, an industrial manufacturer, a partnership with the Eckstein family in <a href="Marquette%20Transportation%20Company">Marquette Transportation</a>; a partnership with Alliance management and co-investors in <a href="Alliance%20Laundry%20Systems">Alliance Laundry Systems</a>, the world’s leading commercial laundry equipment manufacturer; and a partnership with Cox Enterprises and its founding family to facilitate the acquisition of Dealertrack. BDT Capital Partners also partnered with the Malnati family to acquire an equity stake in <a href="Lou%20Malnati%27s%20Pizzeria">Lou Malnati's Pizzeria</a> and partnered with founder and CEO Mark Kaufman on an investment in <a href="Athletico%20Physical%20Therapy">Athletico Physical Therapy</a>, a provider of <a href="orthopedic">orthopedic</a> rehabilitation services. Additional minority portfolio investments include <a href="Peet%E2%80%99s%20Coffee%20%26amp%3B%20Tea">Peet’s Coffee & Tea</a>, <a href="Caribou%20Coffee">Caribou Coffee</a>, <a href="Einstein%20Bros.%20Bagels">Einstein Bros. Bagels</a> and <a href="Krispy%20Kreme">Krispy Kreme Doughnuts</a>, in addition to JDE and <a href="Keurig%20Green%20Mountain">Keurig Green Mountain</a>, all in partnership with <a href="JAB%20Holding%20Company">JAB</a>, the investment vehicle of the Reimann family from Germany. On June 14, 2019, it was announced that BDT bought a majority stake alongside the Dobson family in the Texas burger chain Whataburger. 
From an advisory standpoint, BDT & Company has advised many leading business-owning families and their companies, including <a href="Alberto-Culver">Alberto-Culver</a>, <a href="Carlson%20Companies">Carlson</a>, <a href="Cox%20Enterprises">Cox Enterprises</a>, <a href="Exor%20%28company%29">EXOR</a>, <a href="Guardian%20Industries">Guardian Industries</a>, <a href="Guthy-Renker">Guthy-Renker</a>, <a href="Hyatt">Hyatt</a>, JAB, <a href="Mars%2C%20Incorporated">Mars</a>, <a href="Molex">Molex</a>, <a href="S.%20C.%20Johnson%20%26amp%3B%20Son">S. C. Johnson & Son</a>, and Wrigley.
Personal life.
Trott serves as a trustee of the <a href="University%20of%20Chicago">University of Chicago</a>, founded the Jeff Metcalf Internship Program and helped to launch the Trott Business Program, which provides undergraduate UChicago students with practical work experience and mentoring. Trott also is a director of <a href="Conservation%20International">Conservation International</a> and in 2011 was inducted into the <a href="Horatio%20Alger%20Association%20of%20Distinguished%20Americans">Horatio Alger Association of Distinguished Americans</a> and now serves as President of the Association.
